descriptionProfile: Nutritional Therapist FdSc, Dip ION, mBANT. Bestselling author. Sharing what I grow, cook, eat & love. Book 3 "Nourish & Glow-The 10 day plan" OUT NOW

posts.description: The easiest, yummiest crab cakes for supper last night. Find the recipe in my spring bounty Eat in Season section at  www.ameliafreer.com Happy Hump Day x

Returning to an old favourite. I've created so many recipes over the years I sometimes forget the best ones. This pear, walnut and prune breakfast bowl from my first book #eatnourishglow is a delicious change from my usual eggs and avocado. Happy day to you all x
Joining the #wisteriahysteria ðŸ’œ Happy weekend everyone x

There can be many reasons why a person can't lose weight beyond their food choices but eating healthily is the best place to start and is a far better focus to have than a specific weight. Use my #PositiveNutritionPyramid to help you plan your meals and if you have weight to lose, you'll see that it starts to work, in a healthy, sustainable way. And if you genuinely are eating well, sleeping and exercising and still can't lose weight then work with a nutritional therapist to help address the underlying cause. #10dayplan #nourishandglow

These lemon, oat crusted fish goujons are one of my favourite recipes from #nourishandglow I used to think that this kind of cooking was really complicated and required lots of skill so I'd avoid even trying but these couldn't be easier and they are so tasty and crunchy. As with all of my recipes  they are #glutenfree and #dairyfree and on their own they tick 2 boxes from the positive nutrition pyramid; protein and starchy carb. I'm making them this weekend and serving with asparagus from the garden and a green salad. If you'd like to join me, the recipe is on page 242 of #10dayplan Check my stories to see the finished result x

British asparagus is about to come into season (officially on St George's Day). One of my hero vegetables, it's brilliantly versatile and can be cooked in so many ways, plus it partners especially well with meat, fish, eggs and cheese. The season is fleeting, so I shall be making the most of it over the coming weeks. These little crab & asparagus tarts have a light almond flour crust and make an elegant lunch or light supper - I shall be serving them up later this week. The recipe is on my site www.ameliafreer.com under â€˜Lunch & Supper Mainsâ€™ in the recipe section. Have a wonderful day x

Iâ€™ve just made a lovely fresh, spring salad with some leftover lamb. Iâ€™ve thrown in some chicory, radish, sugar snaps, asparagus, pea shoots and cucumber and will dress it with a simple extra olive oil & mint dressing with torn mint leaves. It sings spring, donâ€™t you think? Iâ€™m about to catch up in the vegetable garden after my short break away â€“ I canâ€™t believe how quickly things have begun to shoot up. I hope you are all enjoying this lovely Easter break x

Happy Easter from South Africa. Since I was a little girl, Iâ€™ve yearned to watch elephants roaming their natural habitat; such magnificent, majestic creatures, they are unparalleled in my affection (oh, I confess, dogs too!). Itâ€™s thrilling and exhilarating to watch them amble by us. Iâ€™m in heaven here and so grateful for the opportunity. 
Thank you for the wonderful and overwhelming response to my happy news on Friday â€“ the kindness and warmth in your messages means so much. 
Wishing you a very happy Easter x

As you can see, my belly is swelling proudly and I am feeling blessed. The truth is, I didnâ€™t know if Iâ€™d ever become a mother; after years of miscarriage, heartache and being told my chances of conceiving were very slim, it finally happened. Each day feels like a miracle but I have been mindful to tread tentatively in these relatively early days. As my little bump grows confidently, it feels a relief to share my news and I can at last focus on the months ahead with great â€“ and very happy - anticipation. Sending you all love from South Africa x

Easter is almost upon us and Iâ€™ve been asked to share a little inspiration for cooking for family and friends on the day. I love a good, traditional roast; itâ€™s a great opportunity to celebrate seasonal food, especially veg, which I pile high into huge bowls to share. At Easter, itâ€™s lamb in our house, slow-roasted so that it falls off the bone. This recipe calls for garlic, rosemary, black olives and anchovies (these will dissolve into the lamb and help to intensify the flavour of the meat without adding any â€˜fishinessâ€™ â€“ give it a go if you never have, as it works so well) and Iâ€™ve partnered it here with velvety cannellini beans. Serve it all up with zesty fresh spring greens. If you are vegetarian, youâ€™ll find a recipe for a beautifully fragrant Watercress, Pea & Asparagus Herb Tart (GF) on my website that literally sings spring. Do head over to the #eatinseason section on the blog at www.ameliafreer.com, where youâ€™ll find other spring inspired dishes, including a yummy Rhubarb & Custard Tart. x
